name: 'peychaud\'s bitters'
description: Peychaud's Bitters is a bitters distributed by the American Sazerac Company.[1][2] It was originally created around 1830 by Antoine AmÃ©dÃ©e Peychaud, a Creole apothecary from the French colony of Saint-Domingue (now Haiti) who settled in New Orleans, Louisiana in 1795.[3][4] It is a gentian-based bitters, comparable to Angostura bitters, but with a predominant anise aroma combined with a background of mint.[5] Peychaud's Bitters is the definitive component of the Sazerac cocktail. [6][7]
review: #have it from review code already

name: 'bitters'
description: A bitters is traditionally an alcoholic preparation flavored with botanical matter so that the end result is characterized by a bitter, sour, or bittersweet flavor. Numerous longstanding brands of bitters were originally developed as patent medicines, but now are sold as digestifs, sometimes with herbal properties, and cocktail flavorings.
review: #same as one above ^

name: 'orange bitters'
description: Orange bitters is a form of bitters, a cocktail flavoring made from the peels of Seville oranges, cardamom, caraway seed, coriander and burnt sugar in an alcohol base. Orange bitters, which are not to be confused with standard Angostura bitters, are currently enjoying a resurgence among cocktail enthusiasts.[1]Renowned mixologist Gary Regan created Regan's Orange Bitters in the 1990s.[2] Regan's are bottled and sold by the Sazerac Company, whose CEO, Mark Brown, had worked with Regan to create a modern version of these bitters. Since 2006 The Bitter Truth in Germany has produced all natural orange bitters and there are now a number of different brands on the market, including Bittercube and Angostura Orange Bitters.[2]
review: #have two reviews from code already

name: 'absinthe'
description: Absinthe (/ËˆÃ_bsÉªnÎ¸, -sÃ_ÌƒÎ¸/; French: [apsÉ›Ìƒt]) is historically described as a distilled, highly alcoholic beverage (45â€“74% ABV / 90â€“148 U.S. proof).[1][2][3][4] It is an anise-flavoured spirit derived from botanicals, including the flowers and leaves of Artemisia absinthium ("grand wormwood"), together with green anise, sweet fennel, and other medicinal and culinary herbs.[5] Absinthe traditionally has a natural green colour, but may also be colourless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as "la fÃ©e verte" (the green fairy). It is sometimes mistakenly referred to as a liqueur, but it is not traditionally bottled with added sugar and is, therefore, classified as a spirit.[6] Absinthe is traditionally bottled at a high level of alcohol by volume, but it is normally diluted with water prior to being consumed.
review: the jade products are my favourite absinthes. they're all alike to a point, with subtle differences. so far, they all make me feel that spending ?60 a bottle on reasonable absinthes so far has been a waste of money. well worth the money. this has a pale amber with a hint of green colour on pouring, becoming greener on forming a louche. my sense of smell isn't the best, but i can definitely detect angelica and anise, and maybe fennel. for me, the herbal taste is slightly stronger than others i've tried so far, particularly the bitter wormwood taste, yet remaining distinctly creamy - particularly with the bitter, creamy, numbing finish. i can definitely taste the aniseed and angelica with perhaps a hint of licorice, and a mild taste of lime amongst others i can't put my finger on - but less licorice than noted in the jade new orleans. it feels more punchy than others i've tried so far, and amongst one of my favourites. very tasty. like other larger bottles in the range, it's stoppered with a plain cork, so make sure you have a stopper unless you intend to finish the bottle! the small bottles i've tried come with stoppers.

name: 'asperol'
description: Aperol is an Italian apÃ©ritif made of gentian, rhubarb, and cinchona, among other ingredients. Aperol has an alcohol content of 11%â€”less than half that of Campari. Aperol and Campari have the same sugar content,[2] and Aperol is less bitter in taste. Campari is also much darker in color. Aperol to be sold in Germany has an alcohol content of 15% to avoid German container deposit legislation regulations.
review: served with prosecco, soda and a slice of orange, it brought back very nice memories of our summer holiday.excellent with prosecco and a dash of mineral water!!i didn't like the taste (it was mixed with some sparkling apple cider).great as we love the real glasses with it too. fun!fantastic. feels like being on holiday when we have an aperol spritz.love aperol spritz, its so easy to prepare and great aperitif!fantastic drink, i love spritzel aperolexcellent taste, brought back memories of holidays in italy in the sun.3 parts prosecco, 2 parts aperol, 1 part soda poured over ice - pop in some chunks of orange and an olive on a stick - fantastic!wonderful stuff! hooked whilst in venice last week - became my nightly aperitif!had my first taste of this on holdiday in tuscany last month.. now i'm hooked..its bitter & refreshing at the same time..and a true reminder of my italian adventure!lovely drink i drunk it on holiday .at lake gardayes, we also had this drink in alba, italy a few weeks ago. it is soooo good, a fun, pretty and unique drink!rhubarb and rye. had it in new orleans....maybe the best drink, ever!we have been drinking aperol across northern italy for the last 40 years. nobody has given the original way we drank aperol. take a glass and run a piece of lemon round the rim, then dip the rim in sugar. then add about a quarter aperol and three quarters of soda. it is a very refreshing drink, which is low in alcohol, and so, good for driving.had lovely introduction with aperol on a recent holiday in mestre would now like to but some!first drank this in lido di jesolo. it's very refreshing and i was instantl hooked. now no one can go to italy withour bringing us a bottle back!discovered this in verona, a stone's throw from the arena - very romantic. we saw the locals drinking it and asked what it is - "spritz aperol" was the reply, which didn't mean a lot to us, but it was the gorgeous colour which sold it to us. half an hour later it was 'due piu, per favore!'i am hooked.....had it in bologna this weekend....aperol mixed with rosecco, soda, ice, slice of orange.had this great drink in lake garda,after seeing everybody drinking it,also calledspritz.its that good to drink stopped of at bars 3 or 4 times a day,highly recommended.

name: 'banana liqueur'
description: A bottle of banana flavoured liqueur from French maestros Lejay-Lagoute, best-known for their legendary CrÃ¨me de Cassis. Very fruity, this works well in both long drinks or in cocktails.

name: 'benedictine'
description: Unlike other herbal liqueurs, BÃ©nÃ©dictine is not medicinal. Instead, it has the flavor of sweet honey accented with holiday spices, stone fruits, and an herbal nuance. Imagine brandy mixed with gin and sweetened with honey and you'll have a close idea of the intriguing taste of BÃ©nÃ©dictine .
review: i first drank dom benedictine in 1968 and have been drinking it ever since. i'm now 68 and i don't drink it every day, but i have it at least 6 times a year. it's wonderful. i seem to remember it was much paler when i first tasted it, but i'm still very fond of it.magical cure of all know illsbest there isexcellent after opening the bottle, but the taste becomes abysmal a week later. try a wine stopper and/or refrigerate it after opening the bottle.this is an enjoyable liqueur. it reminds me a little of drambuie but it''s much more refined. although definitely herbal the citrus is there - enough to make for an interesting alternative to triple sec in a margarita. if you''re stocking a home bar it''s worth having a bottle of this tucked away at the back.a great and warming herbal liqueur. best on its own. also combines well with brandy in equal quantities to make a b

name: 'blue curaÃ§ao liqueur'
description: Briottet's Blue CuraÃ§ao is a classic example of the famous liqueur made with the zest of bitter and Seville oranges. This will add a citrus character and blue colour to your cocktails, for example when combined with vodka and lemon juice in a Blue Lagoon. A must in cocktails, elaborated in the best tradition from a distillation of orange peels, bringing out a strong citrus smell.  In the mouth comes out the flavour of bitter oranges, from the blossom to the peel.

name: 'crÃ©me de cacao liqueur'
description: CrÃ¨me de Cacao is a sweet alcoholic liqueur (chocolate bean) flavored liqueur, often scented with a hint of vanilla. It is different from chocolate liqueur, which is usually sweeter and more syrupy. It comes in 2 varieties, dark and white. Commonly used in mocha martinis or coffee drinks. This sweet syrup may also be sued to pour over desserts and ice cream.

name: 'crÃ¨me de cacao'
description: CrÃ¨me de Cacao is a sweet alcoholic liqueur (chocolate bean) flavored liqueur, often scented with a hint of vanilla. It is different from chocolate liqueur, which is usually sweeter and more syrupy. It comes in 2 varieties, dark and white. Commonly used in mocha martinis or coffee drinks. This sweet syrup may also be sued to pour over desserts and ice cream.

name: 'crÃ¨me de cassis'
description: Merlet's high quality crÃ¨me de cassis, made from the Noir de Bourgogne variety. Concentrated and fruity with enough sour fruit to balance the liqueur sweetness. Well-balanced liqueur, fruity and mellow, the "Cassis Lejay" is a sure winner among blackcurrant liqueurs.  An aromatic and intensely fruity liqueur that's teaming with ripe blackcurrants, plus subtle hints of raspberry and earthiness. It's sweet but well balanced and is great either in the rocks or in cocktails â€“ mixing it with sparkling for a Kir Royale is a must.

name: 'crÃ¨me de framboise'
description: A beautifully packaged 50cl bottle of raspberry liqueur from the 1950s. The ideal way to add a zingy fruitiness to your cocktails.

name: 'crÃ©me de mure'
description: A wild (sauvage) blackberry liqueur (crÃ¨me de mÃ»re) from Merlet. Made from a combination of Black Diamond, Himalaya and Perle Noire blackberries, this is deep, fruity and complex.
review: beautiful flavour! works perfectly in a bramble.fantastic fruit liqueur. especially good over vanilla ice cream with fresh rasberries.a very smooth and pleasant drink after a good meal or as a blender for champagne.

name: 'crÃ©me de violette'
description: A fabulously intense creme de violette from Bitter Truth. As you would expect from this exalted producer, only the finest ingredients are used - in this case wild alpine violet flowers. This will revolutionise your Aviations. Among the native wildflowers found in the Alps are the Queen Charlotte and March Violets. Elegant in its simplicity, this authentic CrÃ¨me de Violette captures their fragrance, vibrant colors, and taste. Enjoy this liqueur in classic cocktails such as the Blue Moon or Aviation, or as an ingredient in continental cuisine. violetty
review: Lovely flavour, not too overpowering, perfect for cocktails.

name: 'dark crÃ©me de cacao'
description: DeKuyper Creme De Cocao Dark is a sweet chocolate liqueur made with African cacao and vanilla from Madagascar.

name: 'elderflower cordial'
description: A more traditional offering from the creative folk at Urban Cordial. This combines freshly foraged elderflowers and fresh lemon juice for a beguilingly floral cordial. Just add sparkling water, or use it in your favourite cocktail. Made using only natural ingredients, Norfolk Wild Elderflower, with its unmistakable golden colour, evokes scenes of British hedgerows with fresh elderflower and citrus tones.

name: 'schweppes blackcurrant cordial'
description: Schweppes Blackcurrant Flavour Cordial is part of the Schweppes Cordials range. These deliciously fruity drinks come in a range of flavours and are served diluted with water.

name: 'lillet blanc'
description: A top-drawer white wine-based aperitif from Bordeaux, made with local wines blended with fruit brandies and matured in oak for between six to twelve months.
review: essential ingredient for the summer. try a shot of this in just soda or tonic. make a lightweight martini with it 2:1 into gin. especially a martini variant with fruit juices too. but if you're looking for the old kina lillet to make a james bond vesper or a corpse reviver, go for cocchi americano instead.cocchi americano is a fabulous replacement for the original kina lillet.there is still quinine in lillet. the recipe of lillet contains less sugar than the kina lillet one. to to counterbalance, there is less quinine. but this is false to pretend there is no more quinine in lillet. and of course, you still can recreate the james bond favorite vesper with lillet.the original "kina lillet" although not technically a vermouth was somewhat dry due due to the incorporation of the bark of the cinchona tree, which contains quinine. the modern formulation "lillet blanc" was invented for "modern" palates i.e. young drinkers and the quinine has been left out. so if you were hoping to recreate james bond's "vesper" cocktail you're out of luck - kina lillet is no longer sold.the word vermouth comes from the german word for "wormwood", a bitter herb sometimes used to treat upset stomachs, and an essential ingredient for vermouths made by martini and noilly prat, in fact it is the wormwood which imparts the "dryness" in any dry martini.sorry, but why exactly is this not a vermouth? what are the rules? is this an aromatised wine, and if so, why is it not a vermouth?? thx, jimbo85% wine 15 % liquor (this is not vermouth)re: vermouth - i've never thought of lillet as a vermouth, but the label on my bottle says "blended with herbs and fruits". so, unless there is another criteria besides being fortified and blended with herbs/spices i guess it would correctly be considered a vermouth.btw- my favorite vesper is 3oz dry fly gin, 1oz dry fly vodka, splash of lillet and 3 drops fee bros citrus bitters. enjoy!2 drops angustura bitters, splash of lillet, 1 oz chase vodka, 3oz crown jewel gin = the best vesper imaginablethey are both fortified wines, but vermouths are blended with herbs and spices ( like kfc).absolutely delicious on its own chilled or a must have ingredient for my favourite cocktail, the 'vesper'.a must have for any drinks enthusiast.1/2 oz kina lillet 3 oz tanqueray gin1 oz stolichnaya vodkacan anyone explain exactly why lillet is not a vermouth instead of just saying that it isn't one?its not a vermouth.what would be the expected shelf life and what is the best metheod of storage once opened? i want to get a bottle for my vespers but a bottle goes a long way and it's about three times more expensive than most vermouth.excellent by itself, as well.reminds me my mother, in some elegant meetings, had lillet, served chilledgood stufftry it with gordans gin and skimrof vodkalovely, light, golden, floral vermouth, refreshing alternative to extra dry or bianco cinzano and martini. try it long, especially on a hot day, topped up with various fruit juices or even simple lemonade and ice.

name: 'amaretto liqueur'
description: Rich, sweet and syrupy â€“ but not sticky â€“ thereâ€™s a freshness to it, too. As expected, almond is the predominant flavour, expertly balanced by notes of orange, marzipan, orange zest, hints of ginger and honey and a very slight bitterness to offset the sweetness.
review: the best amaretto i've ever had! got it as a christmas present from my bro. not sticky, and lingers in an unobtrusive way. definitely buying again!liquid heavenbeautiful. i'm not one for really sweet stuff, so i wasn't sure but this is refreshingly sweet without being sickly in any way. easily drinkable as refreshing nightcap.a beautiful ameretto that has converted me from disaronno, even my wife likes it.nicest amaretto i have had. very smooth.tastes amazing, puts disaronno to shame!absolutely fantastic!wow ! what a drink!awesome

name: 'amaretto'
description: Amaretto (Italian for "a little bitter") is a sweet Italian liqueur that originated in Saronno, Italy. While originally flavoured from bitter almonds, various modern commercial brands are prepared from a base of apricot stones, peach stones, or almonds, all of which are natural sources of the benzaldehyde that provides the principal almond-like flavour of the liqueur.[1][2] When served as a beverage, amaretto can be drunk by itself, used as an ingredient to create several popular mixed drinks, or added to coffee. Amaretto is also commonly used in culinary applications.
review: very good tasteyes! it's very smooth with a tropical punch and slice of lemonthe best amaretto on the market. only brand i use to make home made vanilla.this & jack daniels are my top drink's, not getting any nicer than them!disaronno and a splash of cranberry. a chicks drink for sure!first time i tried this was about 3 years ago at a campout someone had it and passed me it, i tasted it and first thing i said was, "taste like cake! like battenberg", seems you agree! :) this is lovely, as its only 28% its easy and best drinking on the rocks, although is great with coke or gingersimply gorgeous!margaret ktastes like dr pepper !love good marzipan so love this tooadam johnson of mcfc likes this drinka love this drink!add equal quantity of jack daniels to amaretto on ice is a fabulous drink and a lovely winter warming drinkfantastic on ice cream.a great liqueur, but it is a strongly marzipan flavour. so depends if you are a marzipan lover ! however, a sicilian kiss where you mix it with southern comfort in equal quantities is a well balanced cocktail. a favourite of our head foxicologist !is there a similar drink to this, if yes please reply. because i need this as part of an ingrediant to my banoffe pie but this is a very expensive drink so i was woundering if there is a cheaper version of something similar . thanks very much ,is there a similar drink to this, if yes please reply. because i need this as part of an ingrediant to my banoffe pie but this is a very expensive drink so i was woundering if there is a cheaper version of something similar . thanks very much ,very nice drink. became a firm favourite when mixed with coke (has a good taste of flat dr.pepper). or same mix, with blackcurran added. all around very nice drinkbeautiful drink. has a strong taste of amaretto. very much like marzipan. nice on the rocks or added to sweeten a screwdriver, it's nice all around.

name: 'calvados'
description: Lecompte's 5 Year Old Calvados is light and fruity. The combination of apple and vanilla notes allows it to work well in cocktails and long drinks. Introduced to the range in 2014, Roger Groult's 12 Year Old is a complex Calvados with notes of mature apples, candied orange peel and spice. This can be enjoyed before or after a meal, as well as with chocolate- or apple-based desserts.

name: 'campari'
description: An Italian bitter liqueur aperitif created in the 19th century in a coffee shop in Milan by Gaspare Campari. Flavoured with a bewildering array of 68 herbs and spices.
review: i bought two bottles of this for the free glasses which are quite sturdy unlike the flimsy efforts you usually get with free offerings.i love campari and i have this as an aperitif whenever we go out to dinner.a long time favourite,well worth trying if you have not done so before!my favorite mixer: campari & tonic! refreshing and not too sweet..interesting drink on its own but fantastic as part of a negroni.my favourite bitter. too sweet though, so i usually mix with equal parts of xdry martini, orange juice, or better even, fresh grapefruit juice, a slice of lemon, ice and top with a little sparkling water. san pellegrino aranciata also works well and a drop of whisky never hurts.certainly unique. takes some getting used to. try sipping it full strength over ice.

name: 'maraschino liqueur'
description: A Maraschino Liqueur produced by Stock of Trieste, Italy. With the cherry notes accompanied by an almond hint, we estimate this was bottled in the 1970s.
review: deep, complex flavours, not too sweet - exquisite!

name: 'orange liqueur'
description: An age old recipe combining a citrus fruit-laden distillate with 10 year old brandy to produce a vividly golden, fruity orange liqueur.
review: it tastes very goodvery happy we've been looking for agesfantastic smooth vibrant orange flavor with aftertaste of a premium brandy. good flavored liqueur.quite delicious! smooth, unusual in that not everyone is familiar with it, slightly floral with a heady orange-brandy taste. like all good liqueurs, has a gentle aftertaste.strong hits of orange zest with hints of brandy as an after taste. otherwise a very good orange liqueur. nice in a hot chocolate,

name: 'peach schnapps'
description: A peach-flavoured liqueur from Berentzen, also famed for their sweet Apfelkorn. The brand is a favourite of Brits who have lived in Germany and excellent straight from the freezer.
review: i bought this mostly as an ingredient for a cocktail i wanted to try, but even on it's own it has a good flavour. it has the aroma of ripe peaches, doesn't bite much, and is nicely sweet. good neat or as a sweet ingredient for a cocktail with mostly bitter ingredients to balance each other out.

name: 'raspberry liqueur'
description: A remarkable raspberry liqueur.Bright ruby colour with a fuchsia tint.  The nose is distinctly stony, but on the palate the liveliness of the fruit is surprising and refreshing: round and sharp fruitiness, with an almost antiseptic taste from the thyme.  The raspberries are two native Burgundian varieties, with a large proportion of Scottish fruit as well.  It combines brilliantly with rabbit.

name: 'southern comfort'
description: One of the world's most famous liqueurs, Southern Comfort is made with American grain spirit and peaches and tastes great with traditional lemonade, or with vodka, orange & grenadine: the 'Alabama Slammer'. Southern Comfort is made from 100-percent grain-neutral spirit base (basically vodka), fruit, spices and at times the recipe has included a little bourbon. We spoke to Charles K. Cowdery, who worked at Southern Comfort back in the day, and he said that the recipe at least used to be "grain neutral spirit, sugar, and a fruit concentrate in which the dominant fruit is apricot."
review: i recently finished remnants of a litre bottle from the 90â€™s. a truly 5* drink on its own or with ice & lemonade at any time/ any occasion!!this takes me back to the late 70s / early 80s, it may have tasted better then but it maybe me, i will be buying again soon.the 100 proof is the real deal - i don't even bother with the lower proof one, they taste so different.the best drink ever!this is an exelent product, it world be nice if i can buy it in germany.excellent more bite really nicei think its amazingi have a colleague who is bringing me the southern comfort 100 proof direct from the usa. i must admit, there is nothing to compare this tast. i don't even drink it on ice because i think it takes to much of the taste away.i live in oz and traveled to the us as well. just wish it was easily available in the uk. taste is wonderful but be careful. no where near as sweet at the 35% . good with ginger ale but a shame to dilute it. stick with ice.i recently enjoyed the 70 proof original along with a dozen other popular whiskeys. southern comfort was my favorite out of the lot. heck, sc is so incredibly tasty it may dethrone my affinity for all things jim beam. i'd give it 6-stars if they'd let me.smooth and delicious, also fantastic as the alcohol in christmas cake!6/2/16 just bought a bottle of 70 proof and it has very little flavor - have been drinking this for over 50 years, what is up? 100 proof was to intoxicating for me.best of all the southern comfort rangeawesome stuff. sneaks up on you though so be careful how much you are drinking.i frickin lovebit! my sister-in-law brings me a couple of bottles at xmas each year and iblooooove it with aslice of lime ice and ginger ale! bring it to the uk! ?i live in the us i go around the corner to get it, and it's the best ever with pineapple juicefirst tried this when i bought it through duty free coming back from florida. the stuff is amazing. so smooth and for something as strong as it is it doesnt really reflect that in the taste of the drink. its not harsh at all and is easily quaffable straight with some ice. it also mixes beautifully with lemonade.awesome stuff, smooth yet potent. can't wait until it's back in stock!discovered sc 100 proof on at trip to the us 10 years ago (actually visited the plantation pictured on the bottle a couple days later). have been looking for it ever since and visited lots of taxfreeshops all over europe. but no... then i found out that the whiskey exhange had it, and on a trip over from norway, where i live, i bought four bottles... oh joy!!! :-)best ?40 i ever spent. this sc has a fantastic kick to it and is just what you need after a stressful day.don't overdo it though, you need to respect this stuff.great service from the whisky exchange too...

name: 'triple sec'

name: 'aromatic bitters'
description: The herbal essences of Angostura bitters are well-suited for whiskey and rum drinks and add structure and complexity to fruity cocktailsServe an Old Fashioned classic cocktail at your bar, restaurant, or lounge made with whiskey, bitters, sugar, and waterAngostura bitters can also be used in mojitos, Manhattans, Island Breezes, and moreBitter and tangy to the taste, bitters are reminiscent of cinnamon, cardamom, anise, and cloves.Known to enhance the flavor of ingredients without masking their true flavor, bitters are also known as a restorative concentrate that may help ease an upset stomach
review: 4.0 out of 5 starsA16oz bottle is too big for dashingDecember 29, 2014Color: N/aVerified PurchaseWhile I love angostura bitters, I wanted to give this packaging a four star review instead of five as a bit of a warning--a 16oz bottle is extremely difficult to "dash" from. review: 5.0 out of 5 starsGet this!January 4, 2016Size: 1 PackVerified PurchaseWow! Where has this stuff been all my life? I purchased this for my husband, a Manhattan lover, for Christmas, and it's delicious in cocktails, but a couple of drops puts salad dressings and hot cocoa over the top into the realm of the sublime. It needs to be added to something sweet/savory--it was so delicious in cocoa, I tried some on its own, but "bitter" was the word--paired with a vinaigrette or cherry, or chocolate, wow, oh, wow, oh wow!You're welcome.14 people found this helpfulHelpfulComment Report abuse	James Stoddard5.0 out of 5 starsHere's my favorite way to use my favorite bitters.January 20, 2015Size: 1 PackVerified PurchaseI love this bitters. Here is a recipe for my new favorite drink-This is essentially a Utah sazerac, traditionally made with Absinthe which is very expensive and nearly unavailable at the state run liquor stores here. I substitute a little ouzo, I cannot stress enough how little. I just 'wash' the glass with it and let any extra run out before continuing.2oz. of High West Double RyeThe barest whisper of Ouzo, just the tiniest splash.1-2 dashes of Fee Brothers Black Walnut Bitters ( I like 2 but 1 is probably sufficient.)One decent sized piece of Orange Peel, the less of the white bitter pith the better, I like to shoot for one thumb sized peel of just the zest part of the peel.Throw it all together in a rocks glass over ice and enjoy.

description: Expertly blended with spice and natural flavours, my Captain Morgan Original Spiced Gold is the figurehead of my ship.A secret recipe of adventurous spice & natural flavours that are expertly blended with fine Caribbean rum â€“ then aged in charred white oak barrels to create a taste and colour as rich as a pocketful of gold doubloons. For a smooth and refreshing tasting drink, Captain Morgan Original Spiced Gold is best served in a tankard over ice, with cola and a slice of lime.Tasting Notes: Notes of rich natural vanilla, brown sugar, dried fruit, warming spices with hints of oak, come together to create a perfectly balanced spirit with a smooth finish.Drink responsibly â€“ Captainâ€™s orders!
review: an absolute essential. it's my go-to!smooth enough to be consumed neat. the original spiced rum. mixes well with anything.rubbishit's a great budget rum and a delight with coladefinitely catering for the vanilla market. this is not hard core!"spiced gold" not rum. its a blend of cheap alcohol and some rum and spices. also, only 35% vol. heavy notes of vanilla. if all you are making is rum and cokes, then this will work, but not recommended to drink straight.nice & sweet, first a great vanilla taste then the rum comes through, lovely stuff.half decent with coke, but nothing more than a cheap rum really. expect nothingin my top 5, beautiful over ice with cokeexcellent.loved it. perfect blend of sweetness and the delishiousness of rum.wow...captain morgans spiced is by far the smoothest, most mellow rum around.i personally think its nicer than sailor jerrys and usually cheaper. great with a dash of coke and lime.not as bitter as other spiced rums..in a word gorgeous.vanilla & very sweet. lovely, if you're young and/or have a sweet tooth. the more mature palate might suit the cinnamon based lamb's spiced a little better than this particular chap!i was introduced to morgan spice by a lady colleague at work & wow what a drink ! really enjoyed it, i wonder if there is some morgan spice novelties that you could send me, would appreciate it, if you could, just bought another couple of bottles of the lovely nectar !strongly tastes of vanilla, very easy to drink neat. once you get a taste for it you'll just want some more, just doesn't seem like you're drinking rum.love morgan spice with soda water and ice or sometimes with diet irn brumy favourite spiced rum so far, i've tried both versions of sailor jerry, the original is lovely but as its not available in bars... i drink this and it takes great either with coke/pepsi/ginger ale. i've just bought bacardi oakheart which is also 35% for a comparison.. unknown which i prefer yet!tried the new 'tweaked' version of my favourite drink morgans spice - now captain morgans -captain morgan's spiced is the slightly tweaked new branding for morgan's spiced, as far as i can tell. the liquid should be the same but you'll get an extra word on the label. we'll update the picture once we get it in.i'm confused, this is made by the captain morgans rum company, so how do captain morgans spiced and morgans spiced differ?

name: 'captain morganÂ® original rum'
description: Back in the day I was called a roguish adventurer, sailing the high seas in search of new adventures. After every victorious escapade, I led my crew ashore to Jamaicaâ€™s best taverns. These were the rugged, gritty backstreet bars where only those in the know would go to for the best parties and genuinely great times together.Captain Morgan Jamaica is a rum that embodies the spirit of those backstreet tavern parties â€“ with a rich and full-bodied taste perfect for the modern day buccaneers who seek real, authentic fun with their crew. Tasting Notes: Intensely deep and rich taste, with a smoky cask finish.
review: v goooooodproper dark rum, fantastic.smooth and good tastevery very very goodi liked this rum 40 % long yearsdislike this even with a mixer. brings up images of drowning in tarheavy on molasses but pleasant at the back of it all, certainly more of a mixer than anything else, not in a mojito however. try it with ginger ale/beer and lime for best results as the mellow-molasses taste can offset lighter ingredients.don't like it straight but it is very good in cola or sprite.bog standard rum produced in vast commercial properties. more thasn one distillery apparently creates it. a fine, boutique rum it is not but not all that bad for all that. giants like diageo know how to make something appeal to the masses.i loved it. especially good if accurately poured over pineapple juice without blending.drunk neat it tastes a rich rum with oak a lot like ovd rum but with more of a burn finish but not as much burn as lambs navy rum. its great mixed with cola or on its own if you're more of a single malt drinker then captain morgan's dark rum is the rum for you.does anyone know where to possibly get captain morgan spiced gold as i cant seem to find it on here :(best rum in the world mix a good amount with coke perfectionthe very best rum around especially when accompanied by coke .nice rum. mix with a dark beer and drink like a sailor.a very nice rum, very good with schweppes ginger ale.this rum is very strong, be careful when you drink it, and is like you can only drink it with coca cola, only little rum and much colai up the welshies!you are, of course, correct - with a name like morgan, he would have to be welsh, wouldn't he! schoolboy error, thanks for pointing that out. cheers, tim @ sdl

Â· 5 years ago  Silver Rum With PersonalityIt seems that with every subsequent product, Captain Morgan offer something decidedly better than their traditional spiced rum (at least, before being put in a cocktail). Unlike their previous Silver Spiced Rum, Captain Morgan White Rum has none of the spiced characteristics that have come to define the brand, which might sound counter-intuitive, but they somehow made it work.Captain Morgan White is, as you'd probably expect, a sweet spirit that, for my taste buds, helped make the factors which separate white rum and vodka distinct. The rum can easily be enjoyed on its own, but I see plenty of potential for this in cocktails, much as Captain Morgan Spiced Rum leans itself towards.

name: 'cardhuÂ® 12 year old'
description: A much-loved single malt, Cardhu is an easy-going, charming Speysider. With clean, crisp oak and sweet malt evoking flavours of honeyed flapjacks and home-made caramel squares, this is one for the sweet-toothed among you. While itâ€™s not often seen here in the UK, Cardhu is the biggest selling single malt whisky in Spain, with its soft, sweet character the perfect match for the warm climate. Cardhu 12 is the perfect drink for the summer â€“ it's great on its own, but why not try it with a block of ice, or served long with a splash of water, mizuwari style.
review: hmm. methinks there is a nice full rounded smokey taste. hints of charcoaled pinto bean. accompanied with a tantalising lime on the rocks aroma. i have never before seen such a ripe strawberry undertone in single malt in this price range. exquisite palette. richnessery. whilst maintaining an approachable synergy, keeping a decent level of complexity. 3 out of 5 starsa wonder taste to soothe the soul!best whiskey to drinkanyone that does not like this is not a scotch drinkerwatered down vanilla pound cake with a load of flowers; a sweet party mix. agreeing with jeremy about fantastic 12 year olds to prefer.my favorite single malt!awful. tastes like syrupi very much agree with the last 2 reviewers i am a real lover of 12 year old whiskys. this whisky has great look from the bottle and is a nice color. but apart from that i find it to be very bland it has no kick or any sort of a finish whats so ever. i would never buy this again. so many better 12 year olds out there then this!cardhu is not my favorite, i prefer balvenie doublewood.it just didn't sit well on my palate. slightly bold with something i can't place, but didn't care for. normally i'm pretty good with the range of speysides.i'm not sure if i have even tasted cardhu 12 year old scotch before and if i had i have apparently forgotten it - we actually have a sale at out lcbo outlets in ontario so i picked up a bottle - after having a wee dram i would agree with anonymous' comments about it being "a softer sweeter dalwhinnie" - which makes sense as i really enjoy dalwhinnie - i know that neither are complex or peaty as some would like but perhaps that's why i like both - may not drink either every night but really enjoy them both - glad i picked up the bottle of cardhu - certainly a good addition to the scotch collection.my main go to single malt. a dram or two can really smooth out a bad day. a treat for the palate.cardhu 12 year old it bee cooli'm a guy who tends to go for sherry, peat or coastal malts. i always forget about the "plain" ones. we're in the middle of a heat wave in nyc so i figured i'd give this malt that the spaniards day is so great for warm weather a shot. it reminds me a little bit of a softer sweeter dalwhinnie. on those there is heather/ honey and vanilla. very sweet. on the palate you get something like hazelnut gelato and some underlying fruit. maybe pears? the finish is short with a hint of smoke. there is a short, slightly bitter aftertaste that i can't place that is not unpleasant. great stuff that i might not want all the time but is a great change of pace for dedicated sherries/islay/coastal malt lovermy favourite"nose" (undiluted) fruity, apple blossoms, citrus and then some ashy peat with decaying leaves. "palate" (undiluted) initially gripping before transitioning to very sweet pears, apple, demerara sugar cubes, oak and vanilla. kinda like drinking the syrup of delmonte's fruit cup with a flourish of spice and oak. "finish" (undiluted) peppered malt, a slightest of hints of anise, pomegranate, brazil nuts, and well . . . peppermints.superb. a beautifully smooth whisky without the afterburn some of the more peaty varieties have. excellently priced making this an affordable regular treat.delicious nose and tastesuperit has become my new favorite. smooth with a delightful flavour. oban has moved to the back of the shelf.

name: 'champagne'
description: Champagne (/ÊƒÃ_mËˆpeÉªn/, French: [ÊƒÉ‘ÌƒpaÉ_]) is sparkling wine. Many people use the term Champagne as a generic term for sparkling wine but in some countries, it is illegal to label any product Champagne unless it both comes from the Champagne region and is produced under the rules of the appellation.[1] Specifically, in the EU countries, legally only that sparkling wine which comes from the Champagne region of France can be labelled as Champagne. Where EU law applies, this alcoholic drink is produced from grapes grown in the Champagne region of France following rules that demand, among other things, secondary fermentation of the wine in the bottle to create carbonation, specific vineyard practices, sourcing of grapes exclusively from specific parcels in the Champagne appellation and specific pressing regimes unique to the region.[2]Vineyards in the Champagne region of FrancePrimarily, the grapes Pinot Noir, Pinot Meunier, and Chardonnay are used in the production of almost all Champagne, but a tiny amount of pinot blanc, pinot gris, arbane, and petit meslier are vinified as well. Champagne appellation law allows only grapes grown according to appellation rules in specifically designated plots within the appellation to be used in the production of Champagne.Champagne became associated with royalty in the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries. The leading manufacturers made efforts to associate their Champagnes with nobility and royalty through advertising and packaging, which led to popularity among the emerging middle class.[1] The most prestigious Champagne cellars are located in the cities of Reims and Epernay. [3]

name: 'chocolate bitters'
description: Tall, dark and although not necessarily handsome, most definitely rich: with cocoa butter and dark chocolate to entice the nose, hints of vanilla, cinnamon and bitter tones of gentian and wormwood elicit the palate. The Bitter Truth Chocolate Bitters play exceptionally well with sweet Vermouths and all kinds of aged spirits like Whisk(e)y, Rum, Tequila and Brandy.New bitters for a new era of cocktails. Deep chocolate notes are supported by classic bitter flavors and accented with a hint of spice. Plays perfectly with most dark spirits, rums and tequilas. The Bitter Truth Chocolate Bitters blur the lines between old world bitters and new world flavors. Add a dash to a Manhattan to start exploring its complex flavor or use in a Tequila Old Fashioned to bring forward the spiritâ€™s vegetal flavors.Tasting Notes:Dark, rich and complex. A bitter chocolate nose leads the palate to dark chocolate, cinnamon and spice flavors that are supported by classic European bitter herbs

name: 'chocolate liqueur'
description: Chocolate liqueur is a liqueur that tastes like chocolate.Contents1        History2        Recipes3        Uses4        Varieties4.1        Chocolate liqueur4.2        Chocolate cream liqueur4.3        CrÃ¨me de cacao5        See also6        ReferencesHistoryChocolate liqueur is not a new invention. There is mention, in French, of producing and selling chocolate en liqueur as early as 1666.[1] Context suggests this is a chocolate liqueur, not a chocolate liquor or other chocolate beverage. In New England prior to the 18th century American Revolution, a "chocolate wine" was popular. Its ingredients included sherry, port, chocolate, and sugar.[2] A French manual published in 1780 also describes chocolate liqueur.[3] An 1803 French pharmacy manual includes a recipe for a chocolate liqueur (ratafia de chocolat, also ratafia de cacao).[4] An early 19th-century American cookbook, published in 1825 and preserved in an historical archive in South Carolina, includes a similar recipe.[1] Throughout the 19th century and into the early 20th century, manuals and encyclopedias in French, English, and Spanish give similar recipes. A late 19th century food science manual gives a recipe that includes techniques for clarifying and coloring the liqueur.[5] A similar early 20th century manual gives four recipes.[6]There are several brands of chocolate liqueur on the market; this is attributed to a 1990s "chocolate craze".[2]RecipesEarly 19th century recipes for chocolate liqueur featured whole cocoa beans.[4] A basic modern recipe[7] for making chocolate liqueur at home lists the ingredients chocolate extract, vanilla extract, vodka, and simple syrup. To keep the chocolate extract in suspension and make the liqueur thicker, glycerine may be added. In its purest form, chocolate liqueur is clear; coloring may be added.[5] Recipes for home-made chocolate liqueurs may also include raw eggs as an ingredient, presenting a risk of salmonellosis. Reasonable safety may be achieved by combining the eggs with the alcohol before other ingredients.[8] Earlier, liquor was made by adding the cocoa beans to classic liqueur. Modern chocolate wine can be considered as a subspecies of chocolate liquor.[9]UsesChocolate liqueur can be consumed straight, as an after dinner drink rather than as aperitif. It is used in mixed drinks and in desserts, especially in dessert sauces, cakes, and truffles. A food writer notes that many recipes for chocolate truffle add a small amount of chocolate liqueur to melted chocolate, and warns that adding the liqueur often causes the chocolate to seize.[10] One of the more unusual uses is in chocolate rolled fondant.[11]Arguably the most controversial use may be in connection with a scandal concerning the provenance of certain 17th century bottles of wines said to have belonged to Thomas Jefferson, and traded by Hardy Rodenstock. Benjamin Wallace writes in his book The Billionaire's Vinegar that at a wine tasting of 19th century wines from ChÃ¢teau Latour, provided by Rodenstock, several people noted the wines had a flavor of chocolate liqueur and were fakes.[12] Wine and chocolate are a classic flavor pairing, and this is reflected in some cocktails that combine a strong red wine with a dash of chocolate liqueu

description: A high-quality vodka from Ciroc, made from 'snap frost' grapes that are cold fermented before being distilled in a combination of steel and copper stills. The end result is a crisp and clean-tasting French vodka.
review: Easy to drink, smooth finish with a slight citrus flavor.Bryan Jones 5 January 2008Ciroc has zero after taste and is one of the cleanest vodka's I've ever tasted. As a mixer its loverly also. Very highly recommended.

name: 'clove bitters'
description: The quintessential Christmas spice, cloves add a powerful and intense aroma to cocktails and recipes of all descriptions.These Single-Varietal bitters are made using only three ingredients; the spirit (High-proof Dark Rum) and Cloves with natural bittering agents.Used sparingly, these bitters will add depth and intensity to most whisky cocktails, and are especially good in an old-fashioned made with high quality Bourbon, where the Whiskey is really required to shine through.

name: 'coffee bitters'
description: Coffee has become a Saturday morning tradition for Kendall and me.  Before we walk to the market we meet at the best coffee shop in our neighborhood, Contraband, and pick up a couple Cappuccinos to go. Nice, strong espresso with a perfect pillow of frothed milk. Theyâ€™re heavenly. We donâ€™t drink them every Saturday to make us more alert or to get us energized. Although the caffeine is a positive side effect of the beverage, we drink coffee for the ritual and taste.  We drink our coffee slowly, enjoying each sipâ€”this is how I believe a cocktail should be enjoyed as well. For our second batch of bitters, we decided to go with coffee. Coffee is relaxing, it smells good, it tastes good, and it brings people togetherâ€_ who doesnâ€™t love it? A few dashes of Coffee Bitters in a whisky or rum cocktail just sounds like a recipe for happiness. The Coffee-Pecan Bitters recipe in Brad T. Parsonsâ€™ Bitters book inspires the recipe for my Coffee Bitters. If youâ€™re thinking about making your own bitters, or just want to learn some cool facts about bitters, I highly suggest reading it. IMG_2699.jpgTo make my Coffee Bitters, we combined Â_ cup cracked coffee beans, 4 cracked cacao beans, Â_ teaspoon of black peppercorns, Â_ teaspoon cassia chips, Â_ teaspoon wild cherry bark, and 2 star anise in a quart-sized mason jar. For the coffee beans, donâ€™t skimp on the quality. If you use crappy ingredients, youâ€™re going to have crappy bitters. We used Contrabandâ€™s Yemen coffee, which is a medium roast with a sweet and earthy flavorâ€”great stuff. We then drowned the coffee-bark-spice mixture in 2 cups of Wild Turkey 101 (the combination of the bourbon and coffee smells INCREDIBLE, by the way) and kept the jar at room temperature for 2 weeks, shaking the jar once a day.IMG_2742_2.JPGAfter the 2 weeks were up, we strained the liquid through cheesecloth to remove the solids, and then let the solids simmer in a saucepan with 1 cup of water for about 10 minutes. After it cooled, we put the contents of the saucepan in a separate mason jar and let it sit for another week, giving the jar a shake once a day. IMG_3027.jpgIMG_3039.jpgAfter waiting for another week, we strained out the solids and added the liquid to the other mason jar, which contained the original bourbon solution, along with 2 tablespoons of molasses. Three more days of waiting, one more run through cheesecloth, and finally, theyâ€™re done!

name: 'cognac'
description: For the past three centuries, Cognac has been almost universally recognised as the finest of all the spirits that are distilled from grapes. It has many incomparable qualities: fruitiness, subtlety of bouquet, intensity, warmth and, above all, the complexity of the many thousands of styles and flavours from a (predominantly) single grape variety.

name: 'fernet branca'
description: An old bottling of Fernet Branca, a bitter, aromatic Italian spirit. Made using a secret family recipe with 27 herbs emanating from 5 different continents and aged for a year in oak. We estimate this bottle dates from the 1970s.

name: 'fino sherry'
description: XECO Fino is a very modern sherry. So modern, in fact, that its production was crowdfunded. Made by three 'fino fiends' who want to bring sherry to a new audience, this is a dry, citrusy drink that works well with tonic. Please note there are various styles of label, and the bottle you receive may not look exactly as pictured.A citrus-led fino with a touch of nuttiness, the palate is quite fruity and round with good weight. This is a
review: A great summer drink. Perfect ice cold on its own or mixed with tonic!

name: 'french raspberry liqueur'
description: Chambord Liqueur (pronounced [ÊƒÉ‘Ìƒ.bÉ”ÊÅ]) is a 16.5% abv raspberry liqueur modelled after a liqueur produced in the Loire Valley of France during the late 17th century. The Chambord product brand has been owned and produced by the Brown-Forman Corporation since 2006.[1]Chambord is made from red and black raspberries, Madagascar vanilla, Moroccan citrus peel, honey and cognac.Contents1	History2	Production3	Bottle4	Cocktails5	Awards6	References7	External linksHistoryThe Chambord brand was founded in 1982.[2] The drink was inspired by raspberry liqueur made in the Loire Valley in the late 1600s,[2] said to have been introduced to Louis XIV during one of his visits to the chÃ¢teau de Chambord. It was common during that time for liqueurs and cognac to be consumed with elegant meals.In 2006, the Chambord product brand was acquired by the Brown-Forman Corporation.[1]ProductionChambord is produced in the Loire Valley from red and black raspberries, Madagascar vanilla, Moroccan citrus peel, honey and cognac. Whole raspberries and blackberries are steeped in French spirits for a period of several weeks to produce a fruit infusion.After the infusion is extracted, a second set of spirits is added to the fruit and allowed to rest for a few weeks. After this second infusion is drawn off, the remaining fruit is pressed to obtain the natural sugars and juice. The fruit-infused spirits and juices from the final pressing are then combined, and finally, the berry infusion is married with a proprietary blend of cognac, natural vanilla extract, black raspberries, citrus peel, honey, and herbs and spices. The liqueur is 16.5% alcohol by volume.BottleChambord comes in a spherical bottle. Until mid-2010, the bottle came with a metallic gold plastic lettered 'belt' around the middle, and a crown atop its lid. The bottle was modeled after a globus cruciger.In the U.S. market, the manufacturer began using a different bottle design in summer 2010, with modifications to the belt, lid and other elements.[3]In addition to redesigning the bottle for the traditional Chambord liqueur, the manufacturer has also begun using the Chambord brand name on a flavoured vodka.[3]CocktailsCommon drinks made from Chambord include the Raspberry Margarita, French Manhattan, Rolling Green (cocktail)[vodka,lemonade] Butler Miller (Chambord Vodka Gimlet),[4] Kir ImpÃ©rial (Chambord and champagne), Chambord Daiquiri, Chambord Royal Spritzer, Lemonado (Vodka, lemonade and splash of Chambord), Little Purple Men, The Purple Hooter Shooter, Sour Grapes, Black Opal, Peanut Butter and Jelly (with Frangelico or Castries Peanut Cream), Grape Crush, the "Blood of Christ", Grateful Dead, and the French Martini. The French Martini started the "cocktails as a Martini" craze.[5]

name: 'gordon\'sÂ® crisp cucumber gin'
description: This superbly crisp, aromatic cucumber-flavoured gin was launched by Gordon's in 2013. It is based on Gordon's classic London Dry Gin and is flavoured naturally with cucumber. The result is something akin to Hendrick's gin, and it works very well in Gin and Tonics!
review: Loved it, so refreshing & perfect for summer!!

name: 'gordon\'sÂ® london dry gin'
description: Almost 250 years ago, Alexander Gordon started his distillery in London and set about creating the recipe for a brilliant tasting gin. Gordon's high quality and distinctive juniper flavour has come to define the taste of the classic G&T. Gordon's today is a gin that's enjoyed, not dissected. It's the perfect gin to start a Friday evening, or a Tuesday night catch up with friends, where we share a moment and have a laugh with people we love.

name: 'guinessÂ®'
description: Guinness (/ËˆÉ¡ÉªnÉªs/) is a dark Irish dry stout that originated in the brewery of Arthur Guinness at St. James's Gate, Dublin, Ireland, in 1759. It is one of the most successful beer brands worldwide, brewed in almost 50 countries, and available in over 120. [1][2] Sales in 2011 amounted to 850 million litres (220,000,000 US gal).[1] It is popular with the Irish, both in Ireland and abroad. In spite of declining consumption since 2001,[3] it is still the best-selling alcoholic drink in Ireland.[4][5] where Guinness & Co. Brewery makes almost â‚¬2 billion worth annually.
review: Date: Gotta love illegible date codes, I think this is a late 2018 can, consumed on 03/28/19.Appearance: Pours out like a coke, then puts on a beautiful cascading act in the glass. Once this is finished, it takes on the traditional stout look with ruby color around the bottom. Guinness produces over two fingers of what has to be the most creamy sand colored head that a beer ever produced.Aroma: Roasted malts, light coffee, and chocolate are all on the nose with the malts actually seeming to have so depth to them. No one aspect is very pronounced, but it smell nice.Taste: Here is where we have some issues. First, Guinness is terribly thin, not a whole lot more substantial than water. The taste, while presenting a pleasant dry roasted bitter malt profile, never really amounts to much else. Yes, there is some chocolate and a mild coffee flavors, but this is a beer seems fearful of being what it should be. The widget in the can does give it a ridiculously creamy texture though. To sum Guinness up, it has been nice to revisit and old staple, but it simply cannot stand up to its craft brethren such as Deschutes Black Butte Porter. This St. Patrick's Day leftover reminds my why I only buy this once a year. 1,233 charactersDoghouseReilly3946, Apr 10, 2019Photo of mvhissom5/5  rDev +39.7%look: 5 | smell: 5 | taste: 5 black color. Rich and creamy with an absolutely perfect, creamy, white-tan head.Smell: Aroma of bittersweet cocoa, Some roasted grain malt in the background underneath. Some bitterness.Taste: Flavor of milk chocolate, roasted grain malt and even some dark coffee in the background. Encompasses the full flavor profile of a stout.Feel: Oh sooo smooth. Milky. Creamy. Goes down like chocolate milk. It is no wonder the Irish picked this as their staple beer.Overall: When you want a light beer and are considering any of American macrolagers, stop yourself and ask yourself rather whether you want a Guinness. This beer incorporates chocolate, roasted grain malts, and even coffee into a drinkable Irish stout that is so smooth, you'll ask yourself why you don't live in Ireland. It defines the light beer version of a stout. So well done and a tradition, you can't go wrong with a Guinness. 953 charactersdefunksta, Mar 18, 2019Photo of Larryfunnell4.18/5  rDev +16.8%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 4.25 | feel: 4 | overall: 4.25I started drinking Guinness in an Irish bed and breakfast, served to me by a lovely Irish lass just after St. Patrick's Day in 1998. Since then I have had a few every March in celebration. It used to be my gold standard for a stout, and is still good, but lacks some of the character of others with coffee and/or chocolate notes. The beer pours a wonderful dark black and I love watching the bubbles go down the side of the glass. It is not as bitter as I remember, probably due to changing tastes on my part, and has a smooth creamy taste that lingers on the tongue. Overall I quite like it, but not near enough to have an exclusive relationship with it. 661 charactersLarryfunnell, Mar 17, 2019Photo of IronLover3.66/5  rDev +2.2%look: 4.5 | smell: 4 | taste: 3.5 | feel: 3.25 | overall: 3.5From a nitro can. Black in color. Poured with a moderate, creamy, almond white foam with excellent retention. Dark malt and light roasted malt aromas. Medium light bodied with a light creamy feel. Dark malt flavors up front that slowly turn roasty. Roasted flavor expands through the middle introducing bitter roasted flavors and charred malt near the end. Finished dryly with lingering bitter, charred malt flavors that slowly fade. Great look and pleasant aromas. Feel is generally thin and the charred malt flavors hurt the drinkability. Their foreign export stout is far better. 583 charactersIronLover, Mar 17, 2019Photo of ScottP3.87/5  rDev +8.1%look: 4.5 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75ScottP, Mar 17, 2019
